moves.1. f4: I began this game with Bird's Opening, for psychological effect. If I can get my opponent into an opening variation they're not comfortable with, maybe I can force a mistake.
moves.1... e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. d4: I aim to control the black squares. It's a mirror image of the English Opening, where White tries to control the white central squares.
moves.3... Nd7 4. e3 Bb4+ 5. Bd2 Bxd2+ 6. Nbxd: Now that my opponent has castled King-side, I try to focus my attack on that wing.
moves.8... c6 9. Ng5: This brings a second piece to bear on h7 and opens the diagonal for the Queen to move to h5.
moves.9... a6 10. O-O c5 11. Ndf3: Now if the Knight on g5 moves, the Knight on f3 can take its place. The attack is forming up.
moves.11... c4 12. Bxh7+: This was a pure gamble. After this, I have to force my attack through and either win back the sacrificed material or checkmate.
moves.12... Nxh7 13. Nxh7 Kxh7 14. Ng5+ Kg8 15: The only defense against Qh7 mate. But the black King needs some flight squares.
moves.16. Qh4 b5: A tactical mistake. Black should focus on getting the King out of danger, not on advancing the Queen-side Pawns.
moves.17. Rae1 Re8: A good move, clearing space for the King -- provided the e-file remains closed.
moves.18. e4 Kf8 19. exd5: The only chance. If Black doesn't take the bait, I'll probably have to resign in a few moves. I need an open file to get my Rooks active and to cut off Black's flight squares for his King. If Black doesn't capture the pawn on d5, I intend dxe6 fxe6 Nxe6+, which would at least keep the attack going and keep me afloat for the moment.
moves.19... exd5: A huge error. Now the King is deprived of a chance to get away from the attack zone.
moves.20. Qh8+: The logical follow-up, and Black can no longer fight off the attack. A short but very exciting game. I usually play a defensive style, and it was interesting to try something different.
